titleStmt.title: To his ingenious friend M.P. Author of this Poem.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: To his ingenious friend M.P. Author of this Poem.

monogr.title: The nightingale vvarbling forth her owne disaster; or The rape of Philomela. Newly written in English verse, by Martin Parker
monogr.author: M. P. (Martin Parker)

div.head: To his ingenious friend M.P. Author of this Poem.
div.l: I Often have admir'd thy fluent veine,
Composing things of an inferiour straine;
But neither I nor any man could looke,
For such a piece from thee, as this thy booke.
Wert thou a scholler then 'twere no rare newes,
But being none can any Reader chuse
But wonder at thy smooth and haughty stile?
Were I not sure thou didst this worke compile,
I'd not beleev't; tush, common sense doth show it,
Tis wit not learning, that can make a Poet.
Proceed with boldnesse then, and let men see,
The Aganippean well doth spring in thee.
